div.p:
Public servants provide service to Canadians that help them reach their potential.
The Foreign Credential Recognition Program provides Canadians with the ability to earn accreditation for formal education completed outside of Canada.
I work for Employment and Social Development Canada in Vancouver.
Why do I have the best job in the world?
Let me tell you about it.
When I decided to become a Federal Public Servant,
I knew I wanted to have a job where I could have real impact on real people.
So I looked for a job that had an element of direct service –
you know, actually working with clients – and Service Canada was the ticket.
They have a philosophy that’s really centered on the principles of service excellence
and the whole organization is committed to it.
So as a Service Canada specialist, I handle files on various issues.
But it isn’t files… it’s about people… families.
And every case is different.
For instance, I’m working on an initiative called the Foreign Credential Recognition program
where we help Canadians get their foreign credentials recognized so they can work in Canada.
So, let’s say a client who is a physician is in the process of relocating to Canada.
He or she could be partway through the immigration process,
and wants to find work as a doctor but his or her credentials are not yet recognized.
I actually have a client with a situation like this.
I’ve spoken with him a few times by phone, but yesterday he came to see me,
and we’re working together to get him connected.
This program brings different departments together,
like Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, Service Canada,
and other parts of Employment and Social Development Canada
to work through Service Canada’s “single window” policy.
It’s a great example of what happens when departments work seamlessly together
so that clients don’t have to go to each one separately.
And THAT makes it way easier for people like this client.
Sometimes the file is quite complex, but often my client just needs some guidance or advice…
but no matter what, it’s always about important things:
helping families, providing Social Insurance Numbers or issuing passports... new beginnings.
You know what? This was my family, thirty years ago.
The things my own parents and aunts and uncles struggled through.
And I get to help people – help them understand how to obtain the services they need, …
and boy, is that satisfying.
